awd_titl_txt: CICI: SSC: Development of a Secure and Privacy-Preserving Workflow Architecture for Dynamic Data Sharing in Scientific Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific cyberinfrastructures embrace collaborative workflows where users can access and share heterogeneous data and computing resources to perform research and education tasks, which catalyze scientific discovery. One such cyberinfrastructure, JetStream, is the first production cloud funded by the NSF for general-purpose science and engineering research and education. Although Jetstream provides basic data storage security and web authentication, its security features do not satisfy the strict requirements involving sensitive data, such as healthcare data with protected health information (PHI). This project builds a secure, holistic and resilient cybersecurity architecture on JetStream so that collaborative research and education projects can share PHI securely between its users.

The secured infrastructure provides comprehensive multi-level protection for the PHI and its workflows through user authentication, fine-tuned data access control, confidentiality, integrity, and traceability. The project implements role-wise passwordless authentication and authorization, cryptography-based hierarchical access control, dual-level key management, and secure digital provenance integrity protection. By employing these, JetStream VMs can guarantee the security, privacy, and integrity of scientific workflows and associated data, thus protecting data and computing resources from internal and external attacks. When applied to healthcare and life-science cyberinfrastructures, it enables sensitive health data to be shared securely, which is an essential requirement for accelerating life science research. The project promotes the use of real clinical data in training to produce enormous educational impacts. The developed secure architecture is generic and applicable to other data and resource sharing environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report - NSF Award# 1839746

Project Title: CICI: SSC: Development of a Secure and Privacy-Preserving Workflow Architecture for Dynamic Data Sharing in Scientific

InfrastructuresRecipient Organization: Indiana University

Project/Grant Period: 09/01/2018 - 08/31/2022

PI: Xukai Zou;   Co-PIs:   Saptarshi Purkayastha and Huanmei Wu

This project developed a secure workflow protection architecture for scientific cyberinfrastructures in general and medical information systems by seamlessly integrating state-of-art security techniques into OpenMRS medical record system in a coherent way. The implemented architecture and system have been utilized and extensively tested at two universities: Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis and Temple University.  The implemented system has been deployed on XSEDE/Jetstream platform, an NSF-supported scientific infrastructure across institutions, as a virtual image (VM), and can be freely downloaded by the public.

The developed system supports roles, role hierarchies, and data hierarchies and workflow, as well as dynamic changes in roles and hierarchical relations. It implemented and integrated several advanced security technologies coherently including role-wise password-less authentication and authorization, cryptography-based hierarchical access control, and dual-level dynamic and efficient key management schemes, and provides multi-level compressive protection from user authentication, to fine-tuned data access and dynamic control, to confidentiality and availability.

The developed secure OpenMRS system allows researchers, educators, practitioners, and students in bioinformatics and health care fields to remotely access and share sensitive PHIs and workflows with flexibility and convenience. It also has the highest security and privacy protection for collaborative research and education purpose.  It can potentially accelerate life-saving discovery. The developed secure and resilient OpenMRS system and related techniques have been used/instructed to the students in bioinformatics and health-related courses at both Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis and Temple University and effectively enhanced students' acquaintance of knowledge in those disciplines as well as cybersecurity.

The developed cybersecurity framework and its implementation over the OpenMRS system as a test case are generic and can be adapted, adopted, and combined with different cyberinfrastructures and dynamic computing systems. The outcomes will guarantee security, privacy, and availability of workflows and associated data, thus protecting data and computing resources from internal and external attacks. 

The project not only developed a secure and dynamic data sharing architecture/system deployed on Jetstream, an NSF-supported public scientific infrastructure but also generated more than ten publications presented and published at premier international conferences and journals. All of those are publicly available for broad dissemination and will have a long-lasting impact on research, education, scientific infrastructures, and collaborative scientific discovery across institutions, nations, and even the global.
